Key Laboratory of Computational Chemistry-Based Natural Antitumor Drug Research &
Development , Liaoning Province ,
School of Traditional Chinese Materia Medica

subSection.paragraph: A R T I C L E I N F O
Quassinoids
Chemical source
Diverse structures
Antitumor activity
Structure-activity relationships
A B S T R A C T

Quassinoids, originating from the oxidative degradation of tetracyclic tirucallane triterpene, are a diverse class of secondary metabolites identifying from nature mostly in Simaroubaceae family. The crucial pharmacological activities and structural complexity of quassinoids have long fascinated scientists due to their medicinal uses, infamous toxicity, and unique biosynthesis. In the past few decades, 482 quassinoids, assigned to 6 skeletons, have been isolated and identified from plants. The names, classes, molecular formula, and plant sources of these secondary metabolites are collated here. This review will be a detailed update of the naturally occurring quassinoids reported from the plant kingdom, providing an in-depth discussion of their diversity, antitumor activities, structure-activity relationship.

The Simaroubaceae family includes 32 genera and more than 170 species of trees and brushes of pantropical distribution ( Alves et al., 2014 ). The bitter taste of all parts of the plants of this family is a touchstone for botanic identification. In the beginning of 19th century, the bitter substances of
Quassia amara
were named as quassin ( E 1840). The complete structure and stereochemistry of quassin and analogues were established when nuclear magnetic resonance techniques were applied to determine the structure of natural products (Z et al., 1962, Z et al., 1961). With the development of separation, purification, and molecular identification technologies, a large number of natural quassinoids have been isolated and identified, and still attract the widespread attention for both their medicinal uses.

Quassinoids are triterpenoids biogenetically derived from (20
R
)- euphol or (20
S
)-tirucallol in the Simaroubaceae family of plants (Fiaschetti1 et al., 2011, Guo et al., 2005 ; Hou¨el et al., 2013). The transformation from triterpenes to quassinoids was accomplished by multi-step oxidative degradation ( Shargel et al., 2004 ). Quassinoids were categorized into 6 groups: C 26 , C 25 , C 20 , C 22 , C 19 and C
18 types
( Fig. 1 ), based on the carbon backbone ( Polonsky et al., 1973 , Polonsky et al., 1985 ).

Since the discovery of quassinoids, the study indicated that quassinoids display a wide range of biological and pharmacological effects, including antitumor, antimalarial, anti-inflammatory, antifeedant, insecticidal, amoebicidal, antiulcer and herbicidal activities (Fiaschetti1 et al., 2011). Nevertheless, due to serious toxicity (hypotension, nausea, vomiting and fever) and poor efficacy, the clinical trials of bruceantin ( 212 ) was failed ( Beutler et al., 2009 ; Cuendet et al., 2004 , L et al., 1982).

There are several key reviews focusing on quassinoids (Fiaschetti1 et al., 2011, Hou¨el et al., 2013; Kawada et al., 1989 ; Li et al., 2019 , Polonsky et al., 1973 , Polonsky et al., 1985 ); however, there are no comprehensive review has been published in the past decade. In 2019, Li and coworkers have written a review on the quassinoids from 2004 to 2018, but only discussed in relation to the phytochemistry and plants sources of 190
quassinoids ( Li et al., 2019 )
. To date, the phytochemistry of quassinoids has made considerable progress, and 482 quassinoids were obtained. Moreover, longifolactone A ( 1) and longifolactone B ( 2 ) are the first members of a new class of quassinoids with an unusual C 26 carbon skeleton ( Yang et al., 2020 ). The discovery not only enriches the structural diversity of quassinoids, but also has provide firm evidence of the biogenetic process from triterpenoid precursors to quassinoids. Moreover, pharmacological activities of quassinoids have also been further studied, especially their anticancer effects. The phytochemistry, anti-tumor activity, plant sources and biosynthesis of quassinoids during the last decades are covered in this review.

All quassinoids are believed to be biosynthesized through the triterpenoid biogenetic pathway, similar to that of the limonoids, another group of naturally occurring terpenoids ( Guo et al., 2005 ). As natural product, the quassinoids have been elaborated in living organisms by complex enzyme systems developed over a long process of evolution. As shown in Fig. 1 , quassinoids are triterpenoids biogenetically derived from (20
R
) apo-euphol or (20
S
) apo-tirucallol. One of the methyl groups at C-4 and four carbon atoms at the end of the side chain have been removed and carbons C-20 to C-23 have been converted to a γ -lactone ring. However, the detailed degradation process of C 30 triterpenoids to C 25 quassinoids has remained ambiguous due to the lack of relevant biogenetic intermediates obtains to date. Recently, the discovery of the two C 26 quassinoids 1 and 2 has provided new insight into understanding the oxidative degradation pathway of
quassinoids ( Yang et al., 2020 )
.

heading.emphasis: 3. Summary of distribution and classification of quassinoids

subSection.paragraph:
The vast majority of quassinoids have been isolated from Simaroubaceae family, with only nothospondin ( 131 ) was derived from
Nothospondias staudtii
which does not belong to Simaroubaceae family ( Diyabalanage et al., 2011 ). The distribution of quassinoids in nature by source genus has been detailed and tallied in Fig. 2 and Table S 1. This review will cover C 26-, C 25-, C 20-, C 19-, C 18- and C 22- quassinodis according to the biosynthetic pathway and classes shown in Fig. 3.

C
26
-quassinoids (class A ): as a relevant biogenetic intermediate, they were isolated from
Eurycoma longifolia
and has been found to support how C 30 triterpenoids are degraded to C 25 -
quassinoids ( Yang et al., 2020 )
.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 1. The biosynthetic pathway of quassinoids.
Fig. 2. The chemical source of quassinoids in Simaroubaceae family.

subSection.paragraph: C 25 -quassinoids (class B ): the C 25 quassinoids constitute a small group within the quassinoids, which originated from C 26 quassinoids by losing one carbon at C-4. Nineteen C 25 -quassinoids are isolated and identified from Picasma , simaba and others species.

C 20 -quassinoids (class C-E): the category is the largest group and serves as the cornerstone for investigation of quassinoids. There are 390 members added in the last decade from Simaroubaceae family, involving three novel skeletons. The tetracyclic variety (class C ) does not have oxygenation at C-20, while the pentacyclic quassinoids (class D and E ) possess additional oxygenation at C-20 that allows for the formation of an additional ring between C-20 and C-11 or C-20 and C-13.

C 19 -quassinoids (class F ): structurally, are the second group of quassinoids, which was evolved from C 20 quassinoids. These quassinoids have been mainly isolated from
E. longifolia
,
Ailanthus altissima
and
Ailanthus excelsa
.

C 18 -quassinoids (class G ): the C 18 -quassinoids are a relatively small class, only six C 18 -quassinoids were isolated from Simaroubaceae
E. longifolia
and
Samadera indica
.

C 22 -quassinoids (class H ): this classification has the characteristics of C 20 -quassinoids, but the partial carbon skeletons have changed. Three secondary metabolites are isolated from
Picrolemma sprucei
and
Picrolemma pseudocoffea
.

In 2020, Wei-Qun Yang et al . reported isolation of the first C 26 quassinoids longifolactone A (1) and longifolactone B (2), obtained from the roots of
Eurycoma longifolia ( Yang et al., 2020 )
. Structurally, compounds 1 and 2 possess an intact gem -dimethyl unit at C-4, making them the first members of a novel class of quassinoids featuring a C 26 backbone (as shown in Fig. 4 ).

This class B is structurally characterized by the occurrence of a furan ring at C-17, and examples have been isolated from various
Picrasma
,
Eurycoma
, S oulamea ,
Simaba
,
Quassia
,
Hannoa
and
Odyendea species.
It is worth noting that two novel skeletons have been identified, according to whether the furan ring are form between C-21 and C-23 (class B 1), or C-17 and C-23 (class B 2).

The class B 2 C 25 -quassinoids Fig. 6 is structurally characterized by the occurrence of a lactone ring at C-13, and examples have been isolated from
Simaba orinocensis
,
Quassia indica
, S
oulamea tomentosa
and
Eurycoma longifolia
( Forgacs et al., 1985 ; Murae et al., 1973 ; Polonsky et al., 1979a ; Polonsky et al., 1981 ). In the past decade, six new quassinoids (13–18) have been reported. Structurally, guanepolide (18) is unusual since it has possess a β - CH 3 group and an α - OH at C-4 ( Polonsky et al., 1981 ).

Odyendene (19) and odyendane (20) Fig. 7 feature an unusual Δ 20,22 double bond, which were isolated from
Odyendea gabonensis ( Forgacs et al., 1985 )
. In 2014, Fang et al. reported a new 20
S
quassinoid perforalactone A (21) with a unique cagelike 2,4-dioxaadamantane ring system, which was not usually encountered in the natural products of the plant kingdom ( Fang et al., 2015 ). Meanwhile, a new biosynthetic related quassinoids perforalactone B (22) was identified from
Harrisonia perforate ( Fang et al., 2015 )
.

document.paragraph: In the last decades, there are 300 new members added, involving two novel skeletons: tetracyclic and pentacyclic. The tetracyclic variety does not have oxygenation at C-20, while the pentacyclic quassinoids possess additional oxygenation at C-20 that allows for the formation of an additional ring.

subSection.paragraph:
The molecules (177–188, 193–201) feature an α , β -unsaturated carbonyl at C-2, while compound 189–192 possess α - OH or α -OCH 3 at C- 2 ( Chen et al., 2011 ; Chumkaew et al., 2017a; Chumkaew et al., 2019 ; Chumkaew et al., 2017b; Diakanamwa et al., 1993 ; Hitotsuyanagi et al., 2001 ; Ishibashi et al., 1983 ; Ishibashi et al., 1984b ; Ishibashi et al., 1984c ; Itokawa et al., 1992a ; Jiwajinda et al., 2001 ; Morita et al., 1993 ; Morita et al., 1990 ; Polonsky et al., 1979b ; Tan et al., 2018 ; Tran et al., 2014 ). Quassinoids 194–196 ( Fig. 12 ) possess an oxygen-containing unit at C-20 ( Diakanamwa et al., 1993 ; Ishibashi et al., 1984c ; Tan et al., 2018 ). Isolated from the root bark of
Ailanthus altissima
, shinjulactone C (201) and ailantinol E (202) have an unusual hexacyclic 1 α ,12 α : 5 α , 13 α -dicyclo-9 β H-picrasane skeleton which are unprecedented and their biogenetic pathway is unknown ( Ishibashi et al., 1983 ).

Shinjulactone F (203) Fig. 13 was the first example of 5 βH -picrasane skeleton with all cis configurations at A / B , B /D and C /D junctures, which was identified from
Ailanthus altissima ( Ishibashi et al., 1984a )
. Quassinoids 204–206 are mainly from
Ailanthus altissima
featuring an oxy-bridge between C-1 and C-11, while compound 205 possess Δ 5,6 double bond at ring B ( Polonsky et al., 1982 ). Moreover, compound 207 possess Δ 4,5 double bond at ring A and compound 209 features Δ 14,15 double bond at ring D ( Itokawa et al., 1993b ; Xu et al., 2020 ). Longifolactone F (208), which was isolated from the roots of
Eurycoma longifolia
, features a C 20 cage-like scaffold with an unprecedented densely functionalized 2,5-dioxatricyclo [5.2.2.0 4,8 ]undecane core ( Yang et al., 2020 ).

heading.emphasis: 4.3.2. Pentacyclic C 20 - quassinoids (class D and E )

subSection.paragraph: Compared to tetracyclic quassinoids, the pentacyclic C 20 -quassinoids present esters at C-15 closely related with cytotoxicity. According to whether the oxide bridges are attached at C-11 and C-13, they may be subdivided into two subtypes, class C (210–325) and D (326–418). Quassinoids 210–325 are characterized by an oxide bridges between C-20 and C-13. According to the degree of unsaturation of ring A , the class is further discussed ( Figs. 14 - 22 ).

As shown in Fig. 16 , pentacyclic quassinoids 303–308 featuring an α , β -unsaturated carbonyl at C-3 are mainly distributed in
Brucea
( Fukamiya et al., 1987 ; Imamura et al., 1993 ; Kim et al., 2004a ; Kim et al., 2004c ; Sakaki et al., 1986 ). Indaquassin D (309) and Indaquassin E (310) possess a isopentane group at C-6, which were isolated from the bark of
Quassia indica ( Koike et al., 1994 )
. Bruceene A (310) and bruceene (311) have a particular exocyclic double bond instead of – CH 3 at C-4 ( Ye et al., 2015 ). Javanicolide C (313) and javanicoside L (314) represents unusual oxygen-containing substituents at C-2 and C-3 ( Kim et al., 2004a ). Furthermore, bruceine K (315), bearing a unique 12, 20-epoxy moiety, was isolated from the ripe fruits of
Brucea javanica ( Zhao et al., 2011 )
.

The 2,3-seco A ring triterpene derivatives were common in the triterpene family ( Hill et al., 2018 ). Analogously, ten 2,3-seco A ring quassinoids (316–325, Fig. 17 ) mainly from
Brucea javanica and Brucea antidysenterica
, were placed in this group ( Imamura et al., 1992 ; Liu et al., 2012 ).

4.3.2.2. Class E quassinoids .
High degree of oxidation is the prominent characteristic of quassinoids. Quassinoids 326–354 ( Fig. 18 ) possess multiple oxygenated groups at both C-1, C-11, C-12, C-14 and C-15 ( Adesanwo et al., 2009 ; Furuno et al., 1984 ; Grieco et al., 1999 ; Grieco et al., 1995 ; Hitotsuyanagi et al., 2001 ; Jacobs et al., 2007 ; Kubo et al., 1992 ; Kubota et al., 1996 ; KUpchan et al., 1974 ; Miyake et al., 2009 ; Morita et al., 1993 ; Morita et al., 1990 ; Ozeki et al., 1998 ; Tan et al., 2018 ; Usami et al., 2010 ; Wang et al., 2013 ). Among them, ailantinol B possess a β - OH and an α - CH 3 at C-13 ( Kubota et al., 1996 ). Compound 331, 353 bears rare β - OH and α - CH 2 OH at C-13, with the exception of an α - CH
3 in
quassinoids ( Morita et al., 1990 ; Niimi et al., 1986 ). Compounds 338, 340, 343 lack oxygenated group at C-15 ( Furuno et al., 1984 ; Kubo et al., 1992 ). Moreover, 14- epi -13,21-dihydroeurycomanone (339) feature an α - OH at C-14 rather β - OH ( Miyake et al., 2009 ). Quassinoids 342, 343 and 347–351 bear a particular exocyclic double bond instead of α - CH 3 at C-13 ( Furuno et al., 1984 ; Tan et al., 2018 ; Wang et al., 2013 ). Compounds 344–346 exhibit rare epoxy group between C-13 and C- 21 in
quassinoids ( Morita et al., 1993 )
.

Novel 1-epi-5-iso-glaucarubolone (396), 1-epi-holacanthone (397) and 1-epi-glaucarubolone (398) ( Fig. 21 ), possess an α - OH group at C-1, were isolated from the twigs and thorns of
Castela polyandra ( Grieco et al., 1999 )
. Moreover, quassinoids 399–400 lack double bond between C-3 and C-4, while compound 401 feature a unique double bond between C-4 and C-5 ( Furuno et al., 1984 ; Joshi et al., 2003 ; Kubo et al., 1993 ).

There are fifteen new C 20 -quassinoids with rearranged carbon skeletons in the review period. The
Ailanthus altissima
and
Ailanthus vilmoriniana
were phytochemically investigated to search for new bioactive constituents, and this resulted in the isolation and identification of quassinoids 402–408 ( Meng et al., 2014 ; Takeya et al., 1997a ; Takeya et al., 1997b ). They were characterized as the C 11 – C 12 bond-cleaved quassinoids shown in Fig. 22 . Among them, vilmorinine A (408) exhibit an ether linkage between C-1 and C-7, which were elucidated by combination of spectroscopic datas, X-ray analysis and computational chemical method ( Takeya et al., 1997a ). Moreover, 409–417 feature a 13 (12 → 11 α )abeo-type or 9 (11 → 12 α )abeo-type rearrangement skeleton, which were isolated from
Ailanthus altissima
and
Eurycoma longifolia
( Ishibashi et al., 1983 ; Meng et al., 2014 ). To the best of our knowledge, only 418 and 419 were aromatized quassinods, occurred in the stem bark of
Ailanthus altissima ( Joshi et al., 2003 )
.

document.paragraph:
C 19 -quassinoids is the second group of quassinoids. The skeleton of these compounds evolved from C 20 -quassinoids through lose C-16 carbon (class E1-3) or C-1 carbon (class E4) ( Fig. 23 ). In 1985, Judith Polonsky and his team have explained the possible biogenetic pathway of C 19 -
quassinoids ( Polonsky et al., 1985 )
. Similarly, under oxidative conditions, C20-quassinoids might undergo cleavage, decarboxylatio and formation of the lactone in succession.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 23. The main skeleton and possible biogenetic pathway of C 19 -quassinoids.

document.paragraph:
Unlike C 20 -quassinoids, C 19 -quassinoids are substituted by hydroxyl at C-2, C-3, C-6, C-11, C-12 and C-13, and there are no other substituents were observed. There are 54 novel C 19 -quassinoids (420–472) with various skeletons in the review period. The class E1, isolated from
Eurycoma spp.
,
Samadera spp.
and
Quassia spp.
, include 24 novel structures (420–443) Fig. 24 ( Ang et al., 2002 ; Ang et al., 2000 ; Govindachari et al., 2001 ; Itokawa et al., 1992b ; Itokawa et al., 1993a ; Kitagawa et al., 1996 ; Koike et al., 1993 ; Koike et al., 1994 ; Kuo et al., 2004 ; Miyake et al., 2009 ; Park et al., 2014 ; Tran et al., 2014 ). Among them, quassinoids 429 and 430 feature an epoxy group between C-3 and C-4 ( Miyake et al., 2009 ). It is characteristic of Δ 5,6 double bond in most C 19 -quassinoids; however, compound 433 possesses a Δ 4,5 double bond ( Miyake et al., 2009 ). Compound 443, obtained from the roots of
Eurycoma longifolia
, substitute lactone group between C-11 and C-13 ( Kuo et al., 2004 ).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 25. Structures of quassinoids 444–452 (class F2 and F3).

document.paragraph:
Only three quassinoids (480–482) ( Fig. 28 ) have been reported from two
Picrolemma species
in this review ( Polonsky et al., 1984 ; Vieira et al., 2000 ; Zukerman-Schpector et al., 1994 ). Structurally, the three C 22 -quassinoids contain a butenolide moiety attached to the A ring, presumably originating from the aldol cyclization of an α -acetoxycarbonyl moiety from the natural C 20 -quassinoids (Hou¨el et al., 2013). It is characteristic of a γ,δ -unsaturated buenolide ring attached at C-1 and C- 2 in neosergeolide (480), 15-deacetylsergeolide (481) and sergeolide (482) exhibit a γ,δ -unsaturated buenolide ring attached at C-3 and C-2 ( Polonsky et al., 1984 ; Vieira et al., 2000 ; Zukerman-Schpector et al., 1994 ).

subSection.paragraph: The experimental pharmacological and clinical investigations carried out during the past several years have shown that the quassinoids have various biological effects including antitumor, antimalarial, anti-inflammatory, antifeedant, insecticidal, amoebicidal, antiulcer and herbicidal activities (Fiaschetti1 et al., 2011, Hou¨el et al., 2013). The quassinoids are renowned for two major pharmacological activities: their antitumor and their antimalarial potential (Hou¨el et al., 2013). In this review, the development of antitumor drugs from quassinoids was summarized. The structure-activity relationships (SAR) and the mechanism of action are also discussed.

document.paragraph:
Cancer is one of leading health hazards and the second leading cause of mortality worldwide. When bruceantin (212) was isolated from the stem bark of
Brucea antidysenteria
in 1975, its application in the treatment of cancer has attracted wide attention of scholars ( Cuendet et al., 2004 ; Kupchan et al., 1975 ). In the past few years, several quassinoids from Simaroubaceae family have been demonstrated to possess antitumor and cytotoxicity activities.

Su et al. tested the cytotoxicity of compound 188, 210–212, 220–221, 236, 263–265, 284, 288 and 312 (class D C 20 -quassinoids) again human cancer cell lines A549, MCF-7 and Bel-7404 ( Su et al., 2013 ). Compound 210, 211 and 220 exhibited noticeable cytotoxicity against cancer cell lines MCF-7 and Bel-7404 (IC 50 < 10 μM), while compound 188, 221, 263, 265, 284, 288 and 312 were found to be inactive towards all the tested cell lines (IC 50 > 50 μM). In addition, as shown in Fig. 29 , an α , β -unsaturated ketone group at C- 2 in ring A are the common structural requirements for optimum cytotoxicity, such as compound 210, 211 and 220. The quassinoids with an ester group at C-15 showed relatively good activity. Comparing the compounds 220 and 221, it was found that the activity of quassinoids with a – CH 2 OH group at C-13 were poor.

Ye Q. M. et al. tested the cytotoxicity of compound 210–211, 220, 234, 239, 253–254, 256, 258, 268, 284–285, 287–288, 300–301 and 311–312 (Class D C 20 -quassinoids, as shown in Fig. 30 ) ( Ye et al., 2015 ). Among them, compound 210, 211, 234 and 239 with an α , β -unsaturated ketone group at C- 2 in ring A exhibited significant cytotoxicity against cancer cell lines A549 and MCF-7 (IC 50 < 1 μM). Among the quassinoids glycosides tested, only compound 258 showed noticeable cytotoxicity.

Wang Y. and his team reported the cytotoxicity of class C quassinoids 173, 169–170, 201, class E quassinoids 195, 338, 342, 350, 354–355, 358, 361, 388–389 and a C 19 -quassinoid 458 against Human cancer cell lines HepG2, Hep 3B and R-HepG2 (as shown in Fig. 31 ) ( Wang et al., 2013 ). In three types of quassinoids, the class D showed noticeable cytotoxicity, but the class B C 20 -quassinoids and C 19 -quassinoids had no cytotoxicity. This suggest that the oxygen bridge ring between C-8 and C-11 may contribute to the cytotoxicity of quassinoids. Besides, the compound with an α , β -unsaturated ketone group at C- 2 in ring A showed more potent activity, such as compounds 338, 350, 388 and 389. And when an ester group at C-15 of quassinoids, their cytotoxicity showed more active, such as compounds 342 and 350. The order of cytotoxicity of compound 338, 388 and 389 is: 388 > 338 > 389. This indicated that the isopentenyl at C-6 may contribute to the cytotoxicity of quassinoids, but there must have an α , β -unsaturated ketone group at C- 2 in ring A.

Three types of quassinoids, including
C 20
-quassinoids,
C 19
-quassinoids and
C 18
-quassinoids, were all tested for cytotoxicity activity against the metastatic human HT-1080 fibrosarcoma cell line by Miyake and his team ( Miyake et al., 2009 ). The result showed that either
C 20
-quassinoids or
C 19
-quassinoids, as long as the quassinoids with an α , β -unsaturated ketone group at C- 2 in ring A , their activity were more potent, such as compound 178, 186, 333 and 420. For class B
C 20
-quassinoids 178, 181, 186 and 198, the β - OH group at C-12 or/and – OH at C-6 may reduce the cytotoxicity. For
C 19
-quassinoids, the cytotoxicity of these compounds was influenced by the lactone at between C-12 and C-14 or lactone at between C-11 and C-13. Compound 443 with a lactone at between C-12 and C-14 showed weak activity, it indicated that the location of lactone might be an important factor of cytotoxicity. The – OH group at C-2 would reduce the cytotoxicity of
C 19
-quassinoids, comparing with the quassinoids with an α , β -unsaturated ketone group at C- 2 in ring A , for example: compounds 404 and 443. The double bond would enhance the cytotoxicity activity, such as compound 434. However, the
C 18
-quassinoids had no cytotoxicity. The detail information is shown in Fig. 32
.

Fig. 30. SAR studies of class D quassinoids against human cancer cells.

heading.emphasis: 5.2. Antitumor activity of quassinoids and mechanism of action

document.paragraph:
Bruceantin (212) was isolated from the stem bark of
Brucea antidysenteria Mill.
and identified as the active ingredient of this tree used against cancer ( Kupchan et al., 1975 ). In the following decades, many researchers have conducted extensive studies on the quassinoids which are the active ingredients of Simaroubaceae family. The studies on the cytotoxicity of quassinoids has been broadly complied in excellent reviews (Fiaschetti1 et al., 2011, Hou¨el et al., 2013). Bruceantin was the first quassinoid introduced in clinical trials. But due to toxicity (hypotension, nausea, vomiting and fever) and poor efficacy, these clinical trials failed ( Beutler et al., 2009 ; Cuendet et al., 2004 , L et al., 1982). Nevertheless, the pharmacological activity and mechanism of quassinoids have attracted extensive attention. In 2011, G. Fiaschetti et al. made a detailed review of the pharmacological mechanism of quassinoids, including ailanthone (195), shinjulactone C (201), brusatol (210), bruceantin (212), brucein D (222), simalikalactone E (248), peninsularinone (332), 15-desacetylundulatone (385), 6 α -tigloyloxychaparrinone (388), shinjulactone B (458), and several other quassinoids (Fiaschetti1 et al., 2011).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 33. Dehydrobruceine B triggers apoptosis in A549 and NCI–H292 cells via mitochondrial pathway.

document.paragraph: Bruceantinol (211) is a novel therapeutic STAT3 inhibitor that could be used either or in combination with MEK inhibitors for the treatment of human colorectal cancer ( Wei et al., 2018 ). The experiment results showed that bruceantinol strongly inhibited STAT3 DNA-binding ability (IC 50 = 2.4 pM), blocked the constitutive and IL-6-induced STAT3 activation in a dose- and time-dependent manner, and suppressed transcription of STAT3 target genes encoding anti-apoptosis factors (MCL-1, PTTG1, and survivin) and cell-cycle regulators (c-Myc). In addition, bruceantinol effectively sensitized MEK inhibitors through repression of p-STAT3 and MCL-1 induction, known resistance mechanism of MEK inhibition.

subSection.paragraph:
In the last decade, 482 quassinoids, including 6 skeletons: C 26 , C 25 , C 20 , C 19 , C 18 and C 22 were identified from plants mostly in the Simaroubaceae family. The distribution and research of C 20 -quassinoids are the most extensive quassinoids and the studies on C 26 -, C 18 - and C 22 - quassinoids are rarely reported. The analysis of distribution of quassinoids in Simaroubaceae family revealed that different plants contain different types of quassinoids. The plant with the most quassinoids reported is
Brucea javanica
, the main quassinoids is class C and C C 20 - quassinoids. And
E. longifolia
is the main source of C 19 -quassinoids. A larger number of class C C 20 -quassinoids have been reported on the phytochemistry research of Picrsma quassioids . Besides, the isolation of
Ailanthus altissma
and
Eurycoma longifolia
was obtained numerous class E C 20 -quassinoids. Moreover, only two C 26 -quassinoids have been reported from
Eurycoma longifolia
.

Quassinoids with structurally unique and complex natural products exhibit a wide range of interesting chemical properties and biological. The high toxicity of quassinoids has hampered their development into new therapeutic agents. In the studies on the structure-activity relationship of quassinoids, the cytotoxicity compounds have the following characteristics: (1) an α , β -unsaturated ketone group at C- 2 in ring A ; (2) an ester group at C-15; (3) class C C 20 -quassinoids exhibited lower cytotoxicity; (4) C 19 -quassinoids could be a potential source of antitumor drugs; (5) quassinoid glycosides may have a negative effect on cytotoxicity activity. As for the other three types of quassinoids ( C 18 , C 22 , C 25 ), the samples are too small to be included in the discussion.

Studies on the pharmacological mechanism of quassinoids indicate that these compounds have the potential to be antitumor drugs. In the current study, bruceantinol (211), bruceantin (212), dehydrobruceine B (277), eurycomanone (349) and other quassinoids have shown great potential for treating cancer. Nevertheless, no drug has been developed so far from these substances. Moreover, the clinical experiments of bruceantin have shown that it has serious toxic and side effects (hypotension, nausea, vomiting and fever). Whether all quassinoids have similar severe toxicity requires further clinical studies. The chemical analysis of the components of the quassinoids has produced a large number of samples, but systematic studies on their pharmacological activities are lacking. A considerable portion of the antitumor of quassinoids remains unknown. And their lipid solubility, oral bioavailability and pharmacokinetic study are only in their infancy. In brief, the research for quassinoids needs to continue.

subSection.paragraph: Zhi-Kang Duan is a master student in Shenyang Pharmaceutical University. He mainly engages in the activity of natural products.
Zhao-Jun Zhang is a graduate student of Shenyang Pharmaceutical University. With an interest in terpenoids chemistry from traditional medicinal herbs.
Shu-Hui Dong is a graduate student of Shenyang Pharmaceutical University. Her research is the guided separation of active lead terpenids from Daphne family.
Yu-Xi Wang received her doctorate in Shenyang Pharmaceutical University in 2020 and is currently majoring in natural products chemistry.

Professor Shao-Jiang Song is dedicated to the research and development of new drugs for the active ingredients of natural medicines. Nearly thousands of active compounds, including more than 600 new compounds, were isolated and identified from natural medicines, which laid a chemical foundation for the research and development of new Chinese medicine, and made a breakthrough in the key technology of industrial preparation of high-purity Chinese medicine reference substances. Pro. Song has published > 200 articles on medicinal plants chemistry for finding bioactive compounds as new antitumor and Anti-Alzheimer’ s disease.

Professor Xiao-Xiao Huang main research direction is the basic research of medicinal substances of traditional Chinese medicine. More than 1000 active ingredients, including more than 500 new compounds, have been isolated from traditional Chinese medicine, such as
Crataegus pinnatifida
,
Picrasma quassioides
,
Ailanthus altissima
,
Daphne genkwa
and
Daphne giraldii
et al. The research focuses on the discovery of optical mixtures and chiral resolution of active ingredients in natural medicines (traditional Chinese medicine).
